AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: large tree characterized by red flowers in spring and brilliant autumn colors
opposite, three pointed lobes; emerging red, becoming green; brilliant red and orange in fall
gray and smooth on younger trees; older trees have shallow fissures
dense red clusters of small, hanging flowers

The Red Maple is an excellent ornamental tree that brings color to the landscape throughout the year. Beginning in early spring, red flowers appear followed by red-tinged leaves that turn green in late spring. In the fall, the leaves turn a dramatic deep scarlet. In the winter, the previous year’s new growth on the stems display red color as do the new buds. The Red Maple, which is the state tree of Rhode Island, has the most widespread distribution of all the tree species in the eastern United States. The Red Maple is adaptable to a wide range of soil conditions. It is excellent at surviving tough urban conditions. Moreover, it has been shown to tolerate flooding and drought. The Red Maple does have limitations. It may develop chlorosis as a response to high alkaline soils. It is also susceptible to frost crack and sunscald. The Red Maple is sometimes called a soft maple, although the wood can be hard and brittle. In the lumber industry, it is considered a soft maple since the wood texture is softer and less dense than the wood of other maples. Nevertheless, Red Maple is often used in furniture making. American pioneers used tannin derived from the bark of the Red Maple to produce dyes and ink. The dyes were particularly useful for shoes, hats and linens. Interestingly, dead leaves of the Red Maple are highly poisonous to horses. Ingestion of 1½ pounds of Red Maple leaves can be toxic; more than this amount can be fatal. The champion Red Maple in the United States can be found in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park along the Tennessee-North Carolina border. It measures 141 feet tall and its trunk is more than seven feet in diameter. The WSU campus is home to two groupings of Red Maples. One is located on the boulevard just south of Krueger Library. The other is in the grassy area between Krueger Library and Minné Hall. The selected cultivar of Red Maple that is found in these groupings of trees is called ‘Northwood’ which was introduced by the University of Minnesota from seedlings growing in northern Minnesota. Its fall color ranges from orange to red-orange.
